title: What is some of the most destructive weapons? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends somewhat on how you define them. Are we talking the top 10 most deadly weapons of all time? Or just those weapons that are good for killing people in large numbers? Do we even have to limit it to weapons used for killing people? I’ll assume the questioner is asking about artifacts, contrivances and devices that are used as weapons. Otherwise we’d have to list things like the human mind that conceives them, the human hand that designs, constructs and wields those weapons. We’d also have to include education and mathematics that we use to create weaponry better than rocks. In no particular order: Nuclear weapons - Fission or thermonuclear, take your pick. Not for use in subtle wars or small engagements. Great of you want to annihilate your opponent and/or quickly destroy significant capabilities. Offset the cost of these weapons against waging a years-long war. Of course, the downsides are you can’t safely occupy the areas you nuked, it sucks for the environment, downwind neighbors of the attacked country might retaliate over the fallout and you’ll increase cancer risks for everyone on the planet. Biological weapons - While we normally think of modern biological weapons like nerve gas, smallpox, ricin and anthrax, bio weapons have been around for centuries. In the middle ages the corpses of dead soldiers were sometimes launched by catapult into fortifications. Attackers believed the stench would kill the defenders when it was the biological infectious bacteria and diseases. The plague spread to Europe via commerce by the movement of infected fleas and ticks on animals and rodents which infected people and livestock, triggering the dark ages. The bad news about using these is once unleashed they can be hard to control and can come back to bite you. Chemical weapons - Winning battles through modern chemistry was never an advertising slogan but it could have been. Using poisonous material to kill opponents is rooted in antiquity. Dipping spear or arrow tips in snake venom or feces were tricks used in ancient times, as was pouring poison into a town’s wells. More modern chemistry gave us mustard gas, chlorine gas, cyanide and phosgene as well as nerve gas compounds. They can be used against people or livestock to deplete food resources. Other types (defoliants) kill plants and can be used against agricultural fields to starve an enemy. The above form the feared NBC trio (Nuclear, Biological and Chemical) that could be unleashed in some future global war. In terms of lethality any of the weapons used in ancient times caused more deaths and casualties in battles than modern weapons. These weapons would include: The Spear - mount a sharp object on a long stick and poke your opponent. Impact & Bladed weapons - Swords, sabers, knives and battle axes caused horrific wounds and some could remove entire limbs. If blood loss didn’t kill you subsequent infections usually did.  Morning Star The English Longbow - The bow and arrow have a long history but it was the English longbow that could create mass casualties in ancient battles. Before gunpowder weapons armies fought in massed formations. These densely packed formations were prime targets for the English longbow. The bow’s longer range and striking power could penetrate wooden shields and in some cases a Knight’s armor at closer ranges. With a range between 300 to 400 yards (275–365 meters) a company of longbow archers were the medieval equivalent to artillery. A mass of arrows could be launched well out of contact range and several volleys could take down scores of combatants. There are accounts of using longbows against marching opponents by firing over a low hill, both concealing the archers and surprising the marching troops.  English Longbow in use by a large formation of archers (note the arrows already in the air). In the pre-gunpowder days battles were waged in closely packed groups wildly charging into each other with sharp objects. Incurring 15% fatalities wasn’t uncommon for the victor of the battle. The losing side would experience the loss of 30% or more of their manpower. The longbow reduced the victor’s losses by hitting the enemy well out of range of their weapons. Gunpowder and the Rifle - The advent of gunpowder was a serious game-changer in warfare as most of us know. While early weapons were awkward and relatively inaccurate smoothbore hand-cannons and muskets they allowed combat at longer ranges than with bladed weapons. The ability to accurately hit a specific target dropped off significantly beyond about 75 yards with the musket. But this wasn’t a serious issue when armies still used large, densely packed formations of men. It was the advent of the rifle - a heavy barreled musket with a rifled barrel and a tightly fitting projectile - that was a major advancement. The rifling put a spin on the projectile, stabilizing it’s flight and making it more accurate at longer ranges. In the hands of a competent marksman a rifleman could hit a man-sized target up to 200 yards away. Artillery (and TNT) - Artillery in the form of cannons existed for more than 100 years before effective explosive shells became the first choice. Early explosive artillery rounds used (low explosive) black powder and both their range and destructive power was limited. Early in the 20th Century German chemists began loading artillery shells with (the high-explosive) trinitrotoluene (TNT). The use of TNT increased the destructive power of each shell and the velocity of steel fragments of the shell. Advancements in how the shells were fused allowed artillery to fire shells that exploded over the battlefield showering soldiers below with hot steel fragments that could penetrate helmets. As artillery became more common in armies it accounted for large numbers of casualties. A formation of soldiers, either marching or forming a skirmish line in a field, was a juicy target for artillery. An exploding shell landed among a formation could kill dozens of men at a time. The refusal of British commanders at the Somme to change their practice of massed infantry attacks against entrenched positions resulted in 54,000 men being killed or wounded in less than 10 hours. Armies (eventually) responded by dispersing their troops over wider areas to avoid giving enemy artillery massed targets. The Machine Gun - The machine gun, like both the English longbow and artillery seriously discouraged dense formations of soldiers. Artillery discouraged the movement of large formations both on the battlefield as well as miles behind the lines. The Machine gun discourages even smaller unit formations. During WW-I when many field commanders still believed in massed charges over open ground, even in daylight, the machine gun became the wholesale dealer of death. The result of this was to divide units as small as platoons and squads into smaller units (fireteams) that could operate together and when needed disperse and still be tactically effective. The Airplane - The airplane, more than anything else, has changed the way armies and battles are fought. If you control the skies over the battlefield you control the movements of your enemy. Where artillery is effective for up to 20–25 miles the airplane is effective for hundreds or thousands of miles. And unlike missiles the airplane is responsive to changing positions and needs of the ground troops. Originally employed for battlefield observation, airplanes quickly became combatants in the skies. It didn’t take too long to turn the airplane into an offensive weapon that could deal artillery-like strikes hundreds of miles away. The German army of the 40s used aircraft as airborne artillery and an early form of close-air support for ground troops. Today’s battlefield with its precision-guided munitions makes the airplane a very effective support weapon for ground troops. Paradoxically, while the lethality of modern weapons has increased the the ability of a modern soldier some 4,000 fold over his pre-gunpowder ancestors, when measured over time, the measurable casualty effects of modern weapons result in far less casualties when measured against the weapons of the past. Much of this is due to the doctrine of dispersing your forces to avoid mass casualties from artillery attacks (to include airborne attacks today). Xerxes’ massive army of over 100,000 at the Battle of Thermopylae would be shredded quickly by a much smaller modern force with modern weapons. Cluster munitions would be highly effective force multipliers allowing a single aircraft to kill hundreds with each weapon dropped. A wing of F-16s dropping cluster bombs, each one capable of saturating a football field sized area, might create casualties in excess of 75%. That’s my list of the top 10 weapons. What do you think I left out?
